claim: As shown in Figure 1, with a number of 11, 2011 was the most productive year for highly cited articles.
title: Figure 1.
caption: Distribution of the 100 articles by publication year.

claim: As shown in Figure 2A, there were 2 retrospective database analysis studies, 14 reviews, 18 randomized controlled trials (RCTs), 1 pilot study, 9 meta-analysis or systematic review studies, 4 guidelines, 42 cohort studies, 3 case-control studies, and 7 case reports or case series studies.
title: Figure 2.
caption: Proportion of the study types. (A) proportions for different designed studies. (B) proportions for study with different evidence levels.

claim: Furthermore, 73 studies had high-level evidence, whereas 27 studies had low-level evidence (Figure 2B).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Proportion of the study types. (A) proportions for different designed studies. (B) proportions for study with different evidence levels.

claim: The top-10 institutions of publication counts are presented in Figure 3A.
title: Figure 3.
caption: The visualized analyses of institution. (A) the top-10 institution with publications. (B) organization cooperation network.

claim: Figure 3B shows the network visualization of the organizations’ co-authorships.
title: Figure 3.
caption: The visualized analyses of institution. (A) the top-10 institution with publications. (B) organization cooperation network.

claim: The 207 organizations formed 52 clusters, and different colors represent different clusters, as shown in Figure 3B.
title: Figure 3.
caption: The visualized analyses of institution. (A) the top-10 institution with publications. (B) organization cooperation network.

claim: To better reflect the contribution and influence of author’s research, we also analyzed the co-citation of authors by VOS viewer and presented the network visualization in Figure 4.
title: Figure 4.
caption: Network visualization of author co-citation. Co-citation: The relatedness of items is determined based on the number of times they are cited together.

claim: The keywords formed six clusters and the network visualization of keywords co-occurrence is shown in Figure 5A.
title: Figure 5.
caption: Information of keywords co-occurrence. (A) Keywords co-occurrence network. (B) Top-10 keywords of total link strength.

claim: The keyword with the highest appearance (31) and link strength (193) was “delirium” (Figure 5B).
title: Figure 5.
caption: Information of keywords co-occurrence. (A) Keywords co-occurrence network. (B) Top-10 keywords of total link strength.

claim: The top-10 co-occurrence keywords also included “risk-factors”, “surgery”, “confusion assessment method”, “elderly patients”, “hip fracture”, “intensive care unit”, “cardiac surgery”, “general anesthesia”, and “risk” Figure 5B).
title: Figure 5.
caption: Information of keywords co-occurrence. (A) Keywords co-occurrence network. (B) Top-10 keywords of total link strength.

claim: In Figure 6, 25 keywords with the highest burst strength are shown in the first column.
title: Figure 6.
caption: Top-25 keywords with the strongest citation bursts. Year, the year that a keyword was firstly cited; strength, the citation burst strength of keywords; begin and end, the duration of keywords burst.
